Thelma Golden

What prompted the founding of Just Above Midtown in 1974?

Linda Goode Bryant

Frankly, there was a belief that | felt we as a community of Black artists and arts
professionals needed to address. | was running the Education Department at
The Studio Museum in Harlem at the time, which included overseeing the Artist-in-
Residence program there. Other artists visited the residents and inevitably the
conversations turned to discussions about the challenges they faced in trying to
get their work shown because, as they putit, “They won't let us, they won't let
us.” And | found myself saying, “Fuck them. Let's just do it ourselves.”

to Who were “they” in 1974?

198 The whole infrastructure of the established art world:
critics, collectors, galleries, museums, other art spaces,
art historians.

T@ And who were you in 1974?

108 I'm pausing because I'm going to say the first thing that
came to mind. | wasa nationalist. | think I've always beena
Black nationalist. | still am. And what does that mean for me?
Every day, I'm bowled over by the resourcefulness, imagina-
tion, and creativity of Black folk. Wherever there is Black
presence, it’s there. And I’ve always just wanted to be around
that, to be part of that, to support that.

There's so much that we're faced with that can cause us
to doubt ourselves or to think we don’t exist exceptas the
flip side of a black-and-white coin. And | just go, “No, look at
our beauty and amazingness. How can you even doubt that?”
| feel that these days—and I’m ancient now, soit could be
generational—there’s a notion that Black exists in the absence
of white, and that’s bullshit. Black exists in the presence of
Blackness. We exist—what we are, who we are, our power—in
our presence, not in the absence of white folks.

T@ This is one of the most profound aspects of JAM’s origin
story and of your vision. Black institutions—and specifically
Black art institutions—are always seen as in response to. That
crystallized for me during an encounter we had with one

of the many people in our professional world who had recently
discovered the history of our culture and JAM's place within
it. This person kept talking about JAM in relation to what was
happening in galleries or in museumsat that time. And you
very calmly but fiercely said, “This wasn’t a reaction to that.
Itwasa total, complete world and idea unto itself." Itwas
the most profound mental and ideological shift around the
notion of cultural specificity. As someone who has traveled.
through many specifically Black institutions—the Black
church, Spelman College, the Studio Museum—can you talk
about this idea of an autonomous Black space versus a
reactionary one?

108 JAM was an autonomous Black space because it was
about our ideas, our visions, our creativity, the things we
made, the things we felt, the relationships we created that
supported us as individuals and collectively. But when!
think back, it also had to do with the moment, when | wasa
child, that it occurred to me that | was an artist. And there
were probably two things that caused that self-realization.

The first one occurred when | was staying at my paternal
grandmother's house. | noticed that she had a tendency

to. go downstairs into the
kitchen early in the morning.
One morning | heard her get
out of bed and go down-
stairs, and I decided to go
downstairs too. | followed
her and attempted to open
the door. It was locked, and
\hadn‘t remembered it ever
being closed. Then | heard
this noise that sounded like
sand being thrown against
the wall. | lay down on my
stomach and looked under
the door. | could see what looked like a white pit of salt, and

\ could smell vinegar. | called, “Grandma Goode, let mein,

let mein.” But she wouldn't. She was singing. | understood
that there was some magic going on behind that door, and

I wanted to be part of it. Later | processed why she hadn’'tlet
me in. She was Pentecostal. When | came out of the womb,
my parents gave me to her. | was raised in the Pentecostal
Church, which is ritualistic. I'm very much still attached to
that—notthe doctrine but the culture of it. Butinto her
Christianity my grandmother incorporated some rituals she
had learned growing up in South Carolina. Her parents were
slaves, and she was part of the first generation born out of
slavery. That was an awakening for me in terms of creativity
and imagination—

T@ Andalsoa Black specificity. Right?

toa Yes.

7° Because what she was holding was a specific way of being
Black in relation to formalized Black institutional structures.
You then revised that relation for yourself. You stepped away
from the Pentecostal Church for various reasons. You had to
step away from historically Black colleges and universities,
particularly the women’s colleges of that era. You then had to
step away from the Studio Museum of that era. You've often
said you wanted to have a space that would allow for risk and
experimentation. Why was that important?

108 Before | get to that, | need to describe the second thing in
my young life that made me realize | was an artist: Mr. Dillard’s
garage. The Dillards were family friends. | was friends with
their five kids. Mr. Dillard had a garage and, once again, it was
locked. And | was just fascinated by that garage. One day
lasked him, “Can I go into the garage?” And he responded,

“No, you can’t go into the garage.” But that didn’t stop me
from asking the next time | went over. “Hey, Mr. Dillard, can
I go into the garage?” “No, you can’t go into the garage.” And
one day | said, “Mr. Dillard, | really want to go into the garage.”
‘And he went, “You can come into the garage today,” and he
opened it. He had collected things that people had discarded,
from dolls to broken chairs, to car parts, to whatever, and he
made them live again through the most amazing magic. And
tome that was like, “If you can take something that people
think has no value and make it have life again... that's artand
I'm an artist. That's what | wantto do.”

Using what you have to create what you need is some-
thing that people who don’t have financial resources do
ina world that is driven by money. You have to take what
you have to create what you need, and what you create is
something that’s coming out of you, your spirit, your soul,
and your passion as life force. So anyway, those are two
long stories.
Amazing. Eventually, you come to the idea of starting a
gallery. You're at the Studio Museum, but you know you want
to open a space. You havea sense of a vision of who the
‘space is for. You make the decision, based on what you
want to create, to geta space on Fifty-Seventh Street, and you
manage to geta lease. Can you describe the first space,
whatit looked like and meant to be on Fifty-Seventh Street?
198 There were three offices on our floor. One was a fabric
store and one was Mario, who was the tailor for everybody,
from Walt Frazier to Miles Davis. On one of the upper floors
there wasa recording studio, Decca. Miles used to record
there and then come down to the tailor. JAM’s space was in
the middle, and it was 724 square feet. It was small. The win-
dows had been covered up, which | thought was perfect fora
gallery. The floor was linoleum. It hadn’t been used in along
time because nobody really wanted a space that small in
between two bigger spaces. Allan Frumkin, who was a major
art dealer at that time, was on the second floor. Terry Dintenfass
wasin the building. There were other galleries in the building.
Artists and friends came to help to lay parquet flooring and
build out JAM’s space.
T@ And the first exhibition?
198 It was called Synthesis, and it was a group exhibition that
featured artists who were working in the abstract continuum
of Western art, and also those working in a more figurative
and representational continuum [see Chronology, p. 29].
Even though my inclinations definitely leaned toward experi-
mental work, it took me a couple years to goin that direction,
Because | did feel a lot of pressure from artists. New York
artists. Benny Andrews, Camille Billops, and Vivian Browne
could be very convincing.
1? When JAM opened, there was a demand to be representa-
‘tional, both from figures in the previous generation, like Romare
Bearden, and from the peers of the artists you were showing.
Can you talk a bit about the landscape of that moment?
tos. In terms of the Black community, there was fierce debate,
between artists making representational art and those mak-
ing nonrepresentational work, about the definition of Black
art. What was Black art? Were artists who made nonrepre-
sentational work “Black artists”? And there wasa kind of rivalry
between artists based on where they lived, between New
York and California artists, anda more subtle one between
Los Angeles and Bay Area artists. Of course, there were Black
artists working throughout the country, notably in Chicago,

oa ee

Boston, and DC, and they were also part of the conversation.
So when | decided JAM was going to show artists based in
New York, California, and elsewhere, New York City artists
made their objections known.

Most Black-run art organizations in Manhattan, Brooklyn,
and Queens tended to exhibit representational work, which
Icalled “red-green-and-black” or “Black-women-nursing-
babies” art because those were common elements. It was
considered nationalist art. | identified as a nationalist, but!
wasn't drawn to that aesthetic. Artist-run organizations such
as Tom Lloyd's Store Front Museum in Queens, Weusi-Nyumba
Ya Sanaa Gallery in Harlem, and Where We At Black Women
Artists created opportunities for Black artists to meet and show
their work. I was at the Studio Museum, and while it was a vi-
brant space, especially for artists, people who walked by the
museum every day or lived across the street were not coming
in. wanted more of them to come into the museum. JAM was
on Fifty-Seventh Street, and Black folks didn’t usually come
to Fifty-Seventh Street then. So engaging folks at JAM who
weren't going into museums was complicated.

T@ Youwere trying to create a different model separate from
the ways the “community”—we put that in quotes—was_
imagined to engage with art, and in direct response to what
Black artists wanted and needed at that time. Can you talk
about the exhibition openings at JAM? Because that would
allow us to then talk about how you created this space that
was different from anything else. | have lived with the stories
of those legendary openings, which were the meetings of

so many worlds and people, not just in the art world, but in
music, fashion, film.

18 The cross-fertilization in that little seven-hundred-square-
foot space was amazing because every segment of the Black
community came in. Whatever their motivations for coming,
however they identified, professionally or creatively, those

Linda Goode Bryant

distinctions started to break down. And people didn’t just
come to the openings; people hung out at the gallery and
came by frequently. It was kind of like the Artist-In-Residence
program at the Studio Museum when | was thera, Folks were
there sharing ideas, relating to one another, being creative,
and just being human together. But the mix at JAM was more
diverse than at the Studio.

And then there were the debates, including the one at
David Hammons's first solo show at JAM [see Chronology,
p. 33]. | first saw the work when it arrived, and | said, “Hmm,
this may need some explanation,” Sol asked Lowery [Stokes
Sims] to write something that we could hand out to people
if they wanted it. She wrote this piece that had her humor in
it; she could have done stand-up. And when David got there
right before people arrived and saw Lowery’s text ona
podium by the door, he said, “Whatis this?” “Read it.""You
can't describe the work to somebody. They have to see this
themselves.” He told me to get rid of Lowery’s essay and | did.
This opening was one of JAM’s largest openings. People
were outside, down in the stairwells, in the lobby, and out the
building—almost as many people as there had been atthe
‘opening of JAM's first exhibit. People were coming in expect-
ing to see body prints, but there weren't any. David told me
he wasn't making more body prints. Instead, he was making
work with brown paper bags, barbecue bones, grease,
and hair. Abstract and figurative artists came and talked about
the work in their different “tribes.” Artists in both groups
were angered by the work. Some confronted David, asking,
“What the fuck is this shit, man?” He just stared and didn’t
say anything. The tension in the room kept building. Finally,
asked everybody to sit down, shut up, and have a conver-
sation. Things got heated. First people said, “You can’t make
art with barbecue bones and hair. Thisisn’t art.” But after a
while someone asked, “Well, why not? Why are you objecting
to what he’s making art with? Why's that a problem?” Those
words kind of sat there until a few more people said, “Wait a
minute. Yeah, why not?”
To Whatisso apparent—particularly in that ‘74 to ‘78 period,
in that set of exhibitions and your first exhibition with David—
is that you were creating the ground for what we now think of
as Black conceptual art, not in relation to a debate about fig-
uration and abstraction, which had ruled the conversations
about Black art for so long, but as this other space that was so
much more expansive and tied to risk and experimentation.

Can you talk about what it meant to be a woman gallerist
inthat moment, particularly in relation to race? How did you
navigate this Black cultural space from the perspective of
being a woman?
198 | experienced a lot of hostility from some of the gallerists
onFifty-Seventh. Some of them couldn't pass up an opportu-

True to its title, Just Above Midtown’s inaugural exhibition
broke through stylistic, generational, and geographical
divides. At the time, the discourse among Black artists
in New York was often framed in terms of the opposition
between figuration and abstraction.’ Likewise, there was
a split between artists living in New York and those living
everywhere else, with mainstream exhibition opportuni-
ties for the latter few and far between.? Synthesis included
works in a wide range of styles by both established New
York artists (Camille Billops, Vivian Browne, Norman Lewis,
and Valerie Maynard) and emerging ones (Russ Thompson
and Randy Williams) as well as by a younger generation
of artists based in Los Angeles (Dan Concholar, Alonzo
Davis, David Hammons, and Suzanne Jackson). Elizabeth
Catlett was the sole artist living abroad, in Mexico.

Among the most imposing works in the show were
two abstract paintings by Lewis, No. 2 (1973; plate 3)
and No. 7 (1973), the former featuring a primarily black
composition enriched by colorful undertones and white
lines, some made with chalk, others the result of the artist
blocking off parts of the canvas before applying pigment.
Jackson's MaeGame (1973; plate 1), another large-scale
painting that was on display, depicts two partial female
figures floating alongside a flower, a bird, and a silhou-
ette of trees that resembles a cluster of people. Homage
to My Young Black Sisters (1968), a wooden sculpture of
an abstracted woman raising her fist, by Catlett, signaled
the historic ties of figurative Black art to the Black Power
movement and connected the different generations of
artists on view. Also included were Browne's paintings
Untitled (Man in Mountain) (plate 2) and For You, both
from 1974, and both featuring a hazy figure reminiscent
of those that populate the artist's Little Men series, which
depicts male archetypes she encountered in her day-to-
day life. The figure in Untitled (Man in Mountain) is sur-
rounded by patterns inspired by her travels to Africa.

Through thelively conversation between the diverse
artworks on the walls, as well as the spirited exchanges
that took place among the large crowd that attended
the opening, JAM charted new territory, offering artists
of color a space where their work was not confined by
a single definition, true to the idea of a “combination of
parts or elements.” —LRT

Agroup of mothers hung out at JAMwith theirchildrenon
Saturday mornings. As they gathered every week, they
wondered, “Why aren't we creating the environment
that we want our kids in?” From their conversations

emerged the Sunshine Circle Preschool, which oper-
ated in West Harlem. Linda Goode Bryant enrolled her
son in the school and debated its pedagogical model
with the other parents, including actor Morgan Freeman
and his wife, Jeanette Bradshaw; jazz producer Carol
Cole; film director and producer Michael Schultz and
his wife, actor Gloria Schultz (whose stage name was
Lauren Jones); and model Barbara Summers. They hired
Suzette Wright, a teacher, to run the classes, which
emphasized experiential learning, treated “art as the
lens for approaching each subject,” avoided gendered
language, andallowed children of differentages to learn
together in a single classroom.‘ Ten children attended
the school during its first year and twenty in its second
and final year. This enterprise illustrated how JAM func-
tioned as a nexus of mutual support for Black creatives
ofall types. The close-knit interdependence at the heart
of the school inadvertently led to its closure when many
of the actors and filmmakers involved migrated to Los
Angeles, a change that also resulted in an “absence of
that type of creative energy” inthe city. —mr

This exhibition was funded by the singer Roberta Flack,
one of several celebrities who frequented JAM, and an
avid supporter of Mallica “Kapo” Reynolds's work. The
Jamaican artist painted portraits of women he knew
well, including Flack (plate 6), as well as biblical figures
like Salome and Solomon, all shown against earth- or
sky-colored backgrounds and with their faces half in
shadow.

Kapo was a famous preacher of Revivalism, a syn-
thesis of Evangelicalism and Afro-descendent cosmol-
ogies—and as such a homegrown form of resistance to
the cultural imperialism that marked colonial rule and
its aftermath. (The name Kapo was short for Captain,
the title often given to Revivalist leaders.)* Moved by a
divine vision, he had started making art in the 1940s.
His teeming group portraits picture his congregation at
St. Michael's Revival Apostolic Tabernacle, in Kingston,
dancing and singing in the spirit, or gathering around an
altar table. There She Go Satan (1974; plate 5) depicts
a robed figure with seven horns and the feet of a bird.
A band of angels hovers above her, while three church
elders, recognizable by their turbans, stand to the side,
signaling that she is beyond redemption”

After Independence, Kapo was, alongside sev-
eral other self-taught artists, celebrated as a symbol of
a nascent national identity. His work was extensively
collected by and prominently exhibited at the National
Gallery of Jamaica, and he was awarded Jamaica's
Order of Distinction in 1982." In his show at JAM, Kapo's

Grease, oil, shine, and slick...words that have a peculer fascination and
preoccupation among Black Americans. Grease, oil, rub, shine. The bane of

all derker Americans was to appear “ashy” - that is, to have visible evidence

of the scaly dryness thet accompanies any situation where the skin is exposed to
“the elements for any length of time. Since this condition was more visibly

evident on their bodies, Black Americans sought to avoid being seen in this

State in public. Daily, as thousands of school children left their homes,

they were inspected by their mothers to make sure they were neat, and !
@reased. Grease was also an important component of the hair straightening

process. It served as a protective shield for the hair shaft against the

Taveges of the hot comb, and served also as the catalyst that resulted

in the end-product-straight, swinging, shining hair, a home-grown version of

the Breck Girl, Long and Silky, etc., etc. of white america. Crinkled hair

just didn't carry the shine like straightened hair!

But grease and oil, while they were important components in the Black American's
life, it was elso his “badge of shame”. The worse sin that this same school child
could commit was to get grease on his homework. It would then be out there. for

all to see - a spot revealing the nitty-gritty of attempting to conform to the
shining, sparkling American Ideal. It also smacked of the worse kind of ethnicity -
it wes about fried chicken, barbeque, fat back, etc., etc., and that was ever

sooo country.

DAVID HAMMONS, in his latest exhibition, GREASY BAGS AND BARBEQUE BONES, at

a level of visual consciousness within the Black experience. Using barbeque bones
end bags with greasy stains, Hammons in the tradition of the dada “founé object”,
and surrealist juxtaposition forces us to look at the refuse of our experience, ~
and see the pecular aesthetic potentialities: patterns that grease: makes, the

patterns to creating his own in a manner similar to the technique of staining
Cenves with diluted pigments, thereby achieving blotted markings and free-form
Shapes. The multiplicity of forms makes direct reference to mass production, the
Super--super market, shopping bags...shopping bags which have doubled as suitcases,

There was a buzz around David Hammons's first solo
show in New York, which JAM's press release promised
would be an “astounding” and “most exciting visual
presentation.”® Shortly before the exhibition opened,
the artist informed Linda Goode Bryant that he would
not be showing his body prints—the works that had first
attracted her attention and were already being collected
by major West Coast museums. Instead, he would pre-
miere new work made by staining shopping bags with
vegetable oil and pork grease, as well as sculptures in
which kinky black hair was affixed to wire in ornamental
patterns. At the exhibition's opening, several painters
were outraged by what they saw as Hammons’s icon-
oclastic materials—sourced from Black barbershops
and supermarkets rather than an art supply store—and
a spirited debate about their artistic validity ensued.”
Critique and love lived in the same space at JAM—both
often sparked by Hammons'‘s example.

In an essay intended for distribution at the exhibi-
tion, titled “In the Land of Dixie Peach,” Metropolitan
Museum curator Lowery Stokes Sims compared the
brown paper bags to the Color Field paintings made in
New York during the 1950s and ‘60s. Hammons like-
wise connected his new work to abstract painting of
the postwar period: “The spots from the grease of the

Bag Lady in Flight (1975), for example, echoed Marcel
Duchamp’s Nude Descending a Staircase (No.2) (1912).
Like Duchamp, Hammons attempted to depict motion
in astill picture, but he transposed the visual flow onto
an allegorical female figure walking down a South Los

the cosmos of high art, they were also resolutely earth-
bound. Across the bottom of Bag Lady is a warning,
printed by the supermarket chain from which Hammons
sourced the bag: “We are ecology minded. This bag will
self-destruct in Mother Earth!”

Goode Bryant satisfied her desire for new body
prints by staging a Print-In during the exhibition run, a
riff on the sit-ins, teach-ins, and love-ins popular at the
time. The event was billed as a “mutually involved . . .
common activity,” an opportunity for participants to
create—with Hammons’s assistance—their own prints,”
which might serve as gifts for loved ones in a period of
“recession, depression, and general lack of no money in

Showing Black artists next to their white counter-
Parts pointed out the asymmetry between the two sides
of the color line: Johns’s Hatteras (1963), a lithograph
that features smeared handprints, entered MoMA’s col-

This distinction was critical to a pragmatic aspect of the
curatorial conceit: As artist Benny Andrews remarked
in his review, JAM was facing “difficult times,” unable to
“pay the rent, utilities and other operating expenses.""
JAM's “new” statements sold, undoubtedly aided by
being conjoined to those that were already viable.

At the time of the exhibition, Saunders was well-
known for his 1967 essay “Black Is a Color.” In retort
to Ishmael Reed’s Black Arts Movement screed on
the Black artist’s responsibilities published earlier

the same year, Saunders argued instead for a vision
of Black art that need not be molded to a “prescribed

. image.”** Statements Known and Statements New
responded to this two-sided, often male polemic by
proposing a third way: a gallery for Black art could
include non-Black artists, as JAM increasingly would
after this exhibition. Might Johns’s Hatteras—named
after a section of the outer banks of North Carolina
that had served as a refuge for fugitive enslaved peo-

Black art, or at least a way of acknowledging the value
of Black life as a source for the well-known statements

As the only nonliving artist on JAM’s roster, Palmer
Hayden was an outlier, yet his work fit squarely with
the gallery's interest in exploring the complexities of
Black representation. Though Hayden's paintings were
controversial throughout his career, which began in

Back from Washington (1938; see below), which was
included in The Many Facets of Palmer Hayden, is a case
in point. It pictures a dapper Black man—presumably
just back from Washington, DC, standing proud with a
smile on his face and a cigar in his mouth—having his
shoes shined by another Black man. The juxtaposition
of these two figures shows Hayden’s awareness of the

breasts rested on their knees, their energies drained."”°

Elastic and sensual, the sculptures abstract bodily forms,
their pendulous appendages resembling both testi-
cles and breasts. In press images, Nengudi is pictured
manipulating the sagging forms, thereby insisting on the
responsiveness beckoned by the series’ title. Some visi-
tors took her invitation literally by replying on a legal pad
provided by the gallery, with one writing, “Beautiful that
you've created how we all begin + end organically.” The
twelve works featured were priced between one hundred
and one thousand dollars, and two of them sold*_ —TJL

Howardena Pindell has traced the significance of cir-
cles—a constant motif in her work—to a particular child-
hood memory: finding a red circle on the bottom of her
and her father’s mugs at a root beer stand in Kentucky.
The shape designated the mugs that people of color
were to use, and therefore stuck with her as a symbol
of racial segregation. Pindell’s obsession with the circle
came from a desire to give it anew meaning.

In 1977, circles—thousands of them—appeared
across the thirteen abstract paintings and drawings in
Pindell’s solo exhibition at JAM, Recent Works with Paper
and Video Drawings. The show, which also featured
thirteen of the artist's “video drawings” (photographs
of drawings onacetate laid on top ofa television screen),
evinced her fascination with not only circles but lines,
grids, arrows, and numbers, all of which she admired
for their form as well as their ability to calculate value or
to identify.** At the time of the show, Pindell was work-
ing as a curator at MoMA, where, as one of few Black
staff members, she developed an acute awareness of
the ways in which institutions uphold racism and sex-
ism2* Her approach to art making was meditative and
methodical, and offered a therapeutic way to process
the events of her day-to-day life. In her free time she
turned to her “bags of holes,”** the chads she had
punched out of painted manila folders and cardstock.
In some works, she methodically inscribed numbers on
individual circles and carefully adhered them in a grid-
like pattern. To make the works included in this show,
Pindell used spray adhesive and paint to build up the
surface of paper with layers of confetti-like chads and
colorful glitter, in a process that combined automatism
and ritual. The resulting works are lyrical, meditative,
and vibrant, unconfined by their flat supports and their
four edges, as well as by the categories of geometry,
abstraction, craft, and fine art. —yK

Houston Conwill’s performances and_ installations
invoked African spiritual practice, personal allegory,
and ritual to explore notions of tradition. Confronting
a diasporic history shaped by transatlantic slavery,
Conwill’s work celebrated survival and imagined future
possibilities for Black existence.”

_ Conwill produced large wall hangings—petri-
-graphs”—by combining latex and rhoplex to create skin-
‘like strips that he then sewed together and embossed
with found objects and symbols, which he referred to
as “‘memory’ images.””* Ten of these elastic works were
shown in the artist’s debut exhibition at JAM. At the

opening, Conwill staged the performance Notes of a
Griot (1978; see above), which demonstrated his inter-
pretation of juju, a term used in West Africa to describe
an object with supernatural powers.” On the gallery
floor were two circular areas composed of sand and
crushed bark, containing handmade stools and a collec-
tion of ritual objects such as flasks and ointments, their
perimeters delineated by gray stones (see plate 31).
Assuming the role of a griot—a West African musician
and storyteller who performs tribal histories—Conwill
sat on one of the stools and recited an invocation
inspired by narratives of his own making and by imani
(faith), one of the Nguzo Saba (Swahili for “seven princi-
ples”) of Kwanzaa.*° He was then joined by Ed Fletcher,
Al Jackson, and Diana Wharton, who played music
and chanted, as well as David Hammons, who whirled
around the room performing a knife dance to dispel
negative energy. Drawing the past into the present,
Conwill’s performances and objects took on the nonlin-
ear temporality of the diasporic experience, with Africa
as a recursive origin point. The juju ceremony, the artist
asserted at the time, “taps a vital source and brings with
it realities of spiritual truths and energies which may
always arise anew.“ —YK

In the titular essay, the authors conceptualized
the “Contextures” movement—its name a portman-
teau of “context” and “textures”—which had, in their
view, been developing since the early 1970s on both
the East and West Coasts. Its members worked in a vari-
ety of nonrepresentational styles but were united in
their radical departure from the self-referential modes
of abstraction that had defined the previous decades.
“After determining and clarifying the inherent proper-
ties of art,” Houston Conwill, Susan Fitzsimmons, David
Hammons, Wendy Ward Ehlers, Howardena Pindell,
and other Contexturalists moved “outside its margin

and wood are positioned around @ book of European
abstract art, a e of a Corner (1977;

see right), which likewise features found objects but
“breaks” from its wooden frame by engaging with its
environment, its composition accentuating the corner
in which it is installed.**

Self-published and self-funded, Contextures is part
of a lineage of Black feminist scholarship produced in
response to the absence of existing critical writing on
Black artists. As Samella S. Lewis and Ruth Waddy had
done in their two-volume Black Artists on Art (1969-71),
Goode Bryant and Philips interviewed artists to ensure
that their voices remained central to the project.** While
Black Artists included few artists making nonrepresen-
tational work, however, Contextures focused specif-
ically on the “abstract continuum.” The introductory
essay, “Abstract American Art: 1945-1978,” situated art-
ists like Ed Clark and William T. Williams within lineages
of Abstract Expressionism and hard-edge painting, rein-
scribing the contributions of African American artists to
the language of abstraction.

Contextures was produced independently from
any single show, but its theoretical framework reverber-
ated across multiple exhibitions.” These included The
Concept as Art (1977) and The Process as Art: In Situ
(1978), both held at JAM, and two shows that Goode
Bryant organized elsewhere: Contextures ‘78, at the

Edward Kennedy “Duke” Ellington School of the Arts,
in Washington, DC (1978), and Remains—The Artist
in Environment, at the Emily Lowe Gallery at Hofstra
University, in Hempstead, New York (1979). —EB

South Africa: Impressions

The Black American photographer Jeanne Moutoussamy-
Ashe (then Moutoussamy) debuted a new body of work
depicting everyday life in apartheid South Africa and
the complex interrelations of people living under its
total system of segregation." Woman in Doorway (1977;
see p. 44), one of the forty-five black-and-white and
color pictures featured, captures an intimate encoun-
ter between photographer and subject, the smile on the
latter's face an acknowledgment of being seen. Another
work, Sally Motlana in Her Store (1978), documents a
prominent political activist and community leader in
Soweto at the grocery she owned in town, in the middle
of a conversation near the meat counter, Breaking from
traditional photographic depictions of heroism, the
image is suffused with a sense of familiarity and focuses
on the quiet power of true connection.

To the Present

In 1974, Linda Goode Bryant and a loyal group of
friends announced the opening of Just Above Midtown.
“A new gallery providing an alternative approach to
viewing,”' JAM conceptualized a model of being to-
gether that was unavailable at other institutions. In the
years immediately preceding JAM’s opening, Goode
Bryant had worked at a variety of art museums, includ-
ing the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she had
held an education fellowship paid for by the Rockefeller
Foundation. The program, which was funded for three
years, aimed to train “the new breed of museum staff
members, the socially concerned art historian or cura-
tor, and the art-wise social worker,” with an eye to “hir-
ing minorities.”? But midway through its funding cycle,
a program officer at the foundation already expressed
concerns about its efficacy, writing, “One fellow appar-
ently has no desire to work in a museum at all!”

The fellows had their own reservations. One
recalled that they got people with defined personalities
and then expected you to sit there and do what you were
told (fanet Olivia Henry). Instead, Goode Bryant left
the program, which was intended to last a year, four
months in for a job as Education Coordinator at The
Studio Museum in Harlem, a position she still held
when she started JAM. Then as now, she wanted “to
create an infrastructure with real-life consequences,”*
near but outside the museum, able to better respond to
the needs of the time.

The needs of artists and artistic communities in
JAM’s moment echo in our own. Consider a few exam-
ples of the types of headlines that have appeared in
the art and popular press since 2020: “A New Gallery
Opens with an All-Black Staff,” “The Swift, Incredible
Rise of a Singular Black Artist,” “A New Vanguard.

Is Reshaping the Art World.”? Uncannily, these recent
stories, which implicitly equate the rising interest in
black art with structural change, might have been
written about the circle of friends and volunteers that
made up JAM, which in its time struggled to get press.
In a present often imagined as existing without viable
alternatives, JAM offers one in which indebtedness,
spirit, and motherhood—value systems not historically
prioritized by institutions like MoMA—provide ways
of acknowledging that we need one another, as well as
models for turning entanglement into creativity.

JAM?’s formation as a gallery was a means to an
end. That end was also an impossibility: the total reor-
ganization of art’s infrastructure. JAM did not envision
creating an all-black artistic program. Its disbelief
in stylistic coherence created an openness to who and
what could find protection under an idea of black art.

It also aimed to create a sense of possibility for artists
and a belief that anyone could become a maker.*
But its business model—which relied on being in the
red—did not pretend to offer a viable avenue for
self-reliance, that hallmark of black excellence. Instead,

it asked how a place for assembly might offer artists
the chance to try things that they might otherwise
deem too costly—told by others (or themselves) that
they shouldn’t take the risk. Could this space incite a
wide-eyed not-knowing, curiosity, and searching with
others? Could that intimacy then be felt in the stuff

of everyday life, or be folded into fantasy and desire?
Unexpectedly, art produced without institutional man-
dates (explicitly demanded or otherwise internalized)
emerged from the heart of New York’s blue-chip com-
mercial gallery district. This is a black and American
story as much as it is a testament to the extraordinary
drive of Linda Goode Bryant, the gallery’s founder and
director, and her ability to cannily make good on the
opportunities at her disposal.

In using what was available to get what it needed,
JAM was dependent on its environment.’ One index
of its resourcefulness can be gleaned from the mate-
rials of the artworks shown at the gallery: socks, lint,
hair, rocks, ribbons, nylon, sand, paper bags. Reusing
discarded or fungible matter, JAM artists evinced
an enterprising sensibility that was matched by the
know-how of the people who worked and volunteered
at JAM. In addition to holding day jobs at a variety of
other cultural institutions, they were animated by what
Kellie Jones calls “the energies of Black feminism” in
her essay in this volume.® My essay was written in rec-
ognition of JAM’s staff, volunteers, and friends (fig. 1);
their voices form its narrative meter.’ Their quotes,
excerpted from oral histories conducted especially
for this project, are italicized. Other selections from
the oral histories punctuate the rest of this book and
appear on its cover. They are at times fractious, even
rancorous, yet in their cacophony foster a sense of
unity. These first-person accounts enrich the stories
told by the myriad records Goode Bryant kept over
the years, which appear throughout this catalogue and
have been a scripture for our research and interpreta~
tion, our process of making and structuring this exhibi-
tion.'° Together, these sources have allowed us to treat

recent work by a generation of artists who had begun
showing a decade earlier. The emergence of these
artists in the 1960s had occurred against the backdrop
of a debate about the utility of a single vision for black
art, but JAM practiced an idea of black art unbound
from individual style or mandate, without rejecting its
predecessors,

Perhaps most underrecognized in the scholarship
on JAM to date is the effect of the gallery’s incubation
of the first generation of black conceptualists, includ-
ing David Hammons, Senga Nengudi, and Randy
‘Williams."* In their work, art making was often para-
doxically authorial and unattributable, unmistakably
recognizable as belonging to all. Likewise, direct expe-
rience and pure idea were a shared font for rendering
and then transforming social reality. The interest in
black signifiers like chicken bones or Thunderbird bot-
tles skewered the two-sided debate between represen-
tation and abstraction—and unintentionally ushered
in the increasing presence of non-black artists. This
openness began with Statements Known and Statements
New (1976) (see Chronology, p. 36), which featured
neo-Dadaists Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns
and other white artists alongside artists of color
under the influence of Marcel Duchamp, including
Hammons and Jorge Luis Rodriguez. When the gallery
moved to Franklin Street, Asian, Native American,
Latinx, and white women artists increasingly found
cover at JAM.

In retrospect, we can see how JAM’s inclusion
of non-black artists offered a model of desegregation
in contradistinction to integration. In 1985, James
Baldwin read the latter for filth, writing, “I’m not sure
I want to be integrated into a burning house. Americans
decided that desegregation meant integration, and,
with this one word, smashed every black institution
in this country.” A generation after the civil rights
movement, Baldwin joined a chorus of black feminist
thinkers who likewise demonstrated integration’s toll
on black kinship structures through the incorporation
of education, housing, and childcare into white cul-
tural norms, rather than the dismantling of inequitable
value systems or resourcing their black counterparts.!¢
As the recently deceased bell hooks wrote, “That shift
from beloved, all-black schools to white schools...
taught me the difference between education as the
practice of freedom and education that merely strives
to reinforce domination.”"”

In the throes of integration, JAM stayed true to
a version of desegregation buoyed by its cooperative
approach. This was evidenced in public programs
geared to families and children, including the Saturday
Mom’s Group and the Sunshine Circle Preschool
(see Chronology, p. 29), as well as its programmatic
emphasis on collaboration. As early as 1976, Goode
Bryant imagined the gallery's Fifty-Seventh Street

building as a “co-operative building concept” in
which some thirty-six galleries would coordinate joint
advertising through a map of the block and monthly
newsletters.'* Her idea for a “vertical museum”'® did
not materialize, but that did not stop Goode Bryant
from attempting other forms of collaboration when
the gallery moved to Tribeca. The performance Blind
Dates (1982) (see Chronology, p. 104), for example,
resulted from three artists working in different disci-
plines coming together, And JAM’s second exhibition
downtown, Dialogues (1980) (see Chronology, p. 89),
was organized in partnership with its new alterna-
tive-art-space neighbors in response to the increase
in exhibitions organized around identarian affinity.
Through this program, JAM welcomed in both artists
and their communities, including those associated
with Interart, Franklin Furnace, the American Indian
Community House, and Basement Workshop. At a
time when feminist artists and artists of color worked
as both presenters and organizers, JAM joined its peers
in gambling on feminist and multicultural collectivity
as a value for a desegregated artworld.

Creative entanglements at JAM were so intense
that it is sometimes hard to distinguish one maker
from another. To give just one example, that authorial
blur occurred when Noah Jemison and David Hammons
dressed up Marquita Pool-Eckert, who was positioned
inside Jorge Luis Rodriguez’s Circulo con cuatro esquinas
(Circle with Four Corners) (1976), installed in his JAM
exhibition Circulos, and lit a candle in front of her
(fig. 2).?°This kind of enmeshment and interpersonal
weave can also happen when you play music together,
or turn off the lights.

The recourse to spirit also emerged from local
needs and conditions. Nengudi made Air Propo at a
time when there were so many people dying in New York
(Senga Nengudi). We were in the middle of it. I remember
watching people walk through Tribeca one day, and the
next they just suddenly weren’t (Tony Whitfield). While
Nengudi and Whitfield described the precariousness
for queer people during the AIDS crisis, prema-
ture death was a condition for many. Too many of the
black men who showed at JAM died young (Kathleen
Goncharov): Charles Abramson at forty-three in 1988,
George Mingo at forty-six in 1996.

Is caring for and about art synonymous with pre-
paring to keep the dead close?** Just Above Midtown:
Changing Spaces is a rickety reenactment, an exhibition
about what happened between nearly 150 exhibitions.
Itis not an attempt to re-create installations with
exactitude, but rather to give observable shape to the
conditions that formed JAM and are still present today,
and, in the process, to make this history available for
others to reconstruct for themselves. How might the
act of recontextualizing the gallery at MoMA reveal
something in the air, unsaid but everywhere present? If
you take for granted the queer, romantic idea that life
is an artwork, JAM can be approached as a durational
conceptual work of art, imagined and materialized,
incomplete and coming into focus. Another yersion of
our show could have involved leaving the gallery walls
blank apart from the titles of JAM’s group exhibitions
and publications—In Recognition, Contextures, The Process

as Art—as prompts for visitors’ collective responses.
But before we could create a new public, we had to
take account of JAM’s publics through the relationships
forged, fought for, and (mostly) kept up.”

Stories of relationships can be gleaned from
pictures, enacted by works of art, and dramatized by
archival materials. Together, they testify to the vivac-
ity and livelihoods that Goode Bryant and the gallery
made possible, In a note from 1977, Nengudi wrote,
“Linda I’m so glad we have a new base for the strug-
gle. Your perseverance is paying off. Take care... and
if there is anything I could do for you out here let me
know. Thanks for being born.” At the top of a 1980
letter artist Sandra Payne sent to Goode Bryant, she
included a photograph of herself captioned, “A Happy
Woman” (fig. 5). Below it, she wrote, “Dear Linda, I
just received a letter with an enclosed check. Thanks so
much for your letter of recommendation—I can now
breath again—Hope to hear from you soon—Toodle-
loo—Love Sandra."

Linda and I decided that we didn’t want to col-
lectivize Marina Abramovié’s 2010 retrospective The
Artist Is Present, in which the artist sat in MoMA’s
Atrium for the duration of the exhibition. (In this
unrealized version, which reconstructs what artist
Lorraine O’Grady called the “dysfunctional family” or
“clubhouse model,”*° Linda is in her windowless office,
as many visitors would have found her back in the day,
surrounded by Kathleen Goncharov, Fred Wilson, and
other artists, writing grants and instigating debates.)
Instead, we placed our trust in telling a story through
artworks—beautiful and beautifully weird—contex-
tualized by the videos Linda shot as well as historical
materials like bills and family photos. Framed on the
wall like the works of art they are, these memory aides
give flesh to the relations between people who hung
out at JAM. When we asked AC Hudgins how we
might re-create the gallery as a character, he suggested,
Buy some cheap wine, get some herb, play some music.
Years ago, David Hammons proposed an even simpler
gesture: “Linda never paid the electric bills; just turn
off the lights.” ** Playing music and playing in the dark
are also elegiac ways of summoning those who have
gone before, too many of whom have transitioned
during the life of this exhibition’s preparation. This
retrospective exhibition is a memorial avant la lettre,
an occasion to give people their flowers while they are
present. It is also a way of emphatically asserting that
while JAM closed its doors, it continues to exert a
spectral force in the present, refusing to be preserved
in amber.

‘Unable to purchase any of the buildings in which
it made its home, JAM made debt the ground zero of
its business model. Rather than title, it ran on bank
and personal loans, credit cards, and presales of art-
works and books, some of which never materialized.
Goode Bryant deferred payments on operational costs
like heat, electricity, and phone bills by negotiating
with bill collectors and taking out new credit cards,
gladly welcoming her ability to pay the interest without
paying down the principal. (Ironically, Goode Bryant
also used the gallery’s status to confer credit worthi-
ness on artists the gallery showed, as when she wrote
a letter of support for Senga Nengudi’s application
to American Express.) A similar principle of defer-
ral operated for staff members when the gallery first
opened. Wé weren’t paid a set amount. You'd get to the
weekend, and I remember thinking, “I need to get paid.”
Tf you got paid, it might be one hundred dollars. It would
be like an as-needed thing (Pat Cummings). Others have
described the remuneration during those years in
starker terms: She never paid any of us....We kind of
aid her (Horace Brockington).

Models for raising capital varied over the gallery’s
twelve-year existence. Before JAM opened, Goode
Bryant received a one-time influx of two thousand
dollars cash from her parents, Floyd and Josephine
Goode, who would continue to give the gallery loans
in times of emergency, In a solicitation letter to other
family members, Goode Bryant offered them gradu-
ated returns on their investment; without the means
to finance the operation, none of them bought in. The
gallery sold art, catalogues, and slides, but sales were
only ever a partial source of earned income. Artist and
creative friends offered personal loans and gifts, the
‘two sometimes indistinguishable. After the organiza-
tion applied for and was awarded nonprofit status in

1975, it qualified for government support.®* It could
also receive funding from foundations, including the
same Rockefeller Foundation that had financed Goode
Bryant's fellowship at the Met. In a letter Petition-

ing the foundation’s program officer, Goode Bryant
wrote, “It is miraculous that this gallery can still open
the doors and provide exhibitions to the public, This
period has been a lengthy and exhausting one, For

all concerned can see the accomplishments that were
achieved with a budget of zero,”

The gallery held event-based fundraisers and
sold memberships, which it advertised as emphasizing
“an interplay between you and the artists.”2” Goode
Bryant was also able to secure corporate grants from
CBS, arts funders Exxon and Mobil Oil, and Con
Edison, although the gallery was often late on its utility
payments to the company. Perhaps the most mean-
ingful form of investment was volunteerism: quiches
prepared by Faythe Weaver for Brunch with JAM (see
Chronology, p. 36), supplies provided to build out the
spaces, childcare for Goode Bryant’s two young kids.
Most of what today’s nonprofits classify as donations
went undocumented in the gallery’s financial records,
as is usually the case for forms of debt that neither
party expects to be repaid.

The threat of debt is no stranger to folks of color.
The history of lending as a means of dispossession
in the Americas extends from unconstrained mortgage
foreclosures on Indigenous land during the English
colonial period and the “external debt” imposed on
Haiti by France and later the United States as ransom
after the defeat of slavery and colonialism;7* to
New York City’s 1975 debt crisis, which was partially
caused by the decrease in tax revenue due to white
flight, and which eventually led to the firing of
thousands of public workers, the majority of whom
were people of color; to the 2008 subprime mortgage
crisis, which was triggered by, among other things,
black and Latinx home buyers being lent money at
exorbitant interest rates precisely because they would
not be able to pay it back.*° Anthropologist David
Graeber has argued that while forms of obligation
have always structured economic relations, the advent
of money made them quantifiable through debt—an
asymmetrical relationship in which creditors are able
to prey on those with less power, including those seek-
ing home ownership without claims of land and title."
Insidiously, the false promise of rootedness became
the tether to indebtedness.

JAM embraced debt—both as an economic
necessity and as a value. In The Undercommons, Stefano
Harney and Fred Moten offer a new valuation of this
denigrated term: “Credit only runs one way. Debt is
mutual.”??Indebtedness—not to a financial institution
but to friends, colleagues, and family members—
necessitated ongoing commitments and relationships
built on reciprocity and duration.»? This kind of
indebtedness explains why volunteers worked at the
gallery in its early years in exchange for having a base
for the struggle they would wage at their day jobs. This
kind of indebtedness clarifies how the gallery could
establish a market for an artist like David Hammons,
who would then sell a benefit print that would keep the
gallery going. It can’t be quantified on a balance sheet,
but it works through a logic of “bad debt”: “debt that
cannot be repaid, incalculable debt, debt broken from.
credit, debt as its own principle.”

Debt is a perverse name for a system that could
also be described through the language of mutual aid
or love. I hold on to it here to more accurately delin-
eate the historical financial conditions and models
that—like other circumscribed protocols (real estate
speculation, the commercial gallery model, a promotion
service involving multiple outlets across the world) —
Goode Bryant reformatted, Just as some of the artists
who showed at JAM reworked lint, hair, or nylon in
their artworks, Goode Bryant marshaled debt toward a
different end than the one set out by her creditors.

What were the other options available to JAM? The
copublishers of this book negotiated their own real estate
deals during this same period. The Studio Museum in
Harlem (founded in 1968) was gifted a building in 1979
by the New York Bank for Savings, and in 1985 it leased
the adjacent vacant lot from the City of New York;
the museum is currently constructing its new home on
this site.** In the mid-1970s, MoMA representatives
proposed and then lobbied New York’s State legislature
to create the Trust for Cultural Resources. This public-
benefit corporation, still in existence, blueprinted an
intricate financial model for cultural institutions in New
York City, clearing the way for MoMA to sell the air
rights above its Fifty-Third Street building and subse-
quently to develop a residential tower. The Trust enabled
some of the proceeds of this new tower to go to MoMA,
helping to capitalize its expansion. The Trust also facil-
itated the exception of taxes on bonds issued to the
Museum, a method of debt retirement. When MoMA
announced these ambitions, New York City’s mayor,
Abraham Beame—who himself had just barely avoided
defaulting on the city’s debts—celebrated the private-
public partnership as a “self-help project” that was
“good news for all New Yorkers.”**

In contrasting these differences in resource allo-
cation, I am not suggesting that there is a zero-sum
relationship between MoMA’s guaranteed forgiveness
and JAM’s unpaid debts. Rather, I juxtapose them
to better understand their historical entanglements,
which function as an index of the interconnectedness
of financial and cultural value in the United States,
particularly when it comes to the things black people
make and the places we stay. Could we, following phi-
losopher and artist Denise Ferreira da Silva, describe
JAM’s debt as unpayable—an obligation that is not the
debtor’s to pay?>”

In her interview with Thelma Golden in this book,
Goode Bryant asks, “Can JAM be JAM at MoMA?”*
‘Why do the two institutions at once refuse and need
one another? That this show is happening at MoMA
is an acknowledgment that JAM, both then and now,
required a Midtown to be just above: a norm to define
itself against, a set of resources made available by
desegregation to siphon off toward more equitable
ends. The debt of our moment to JAM is unpayable
because there is no way to fully acknowledge the

history the gallery made possible, nor the models
for artistic support it continues to actualize through
ongoing relationships. This exhibition may function as
an expanded credit, a dedication, and a resource guide.
But even an attempt at a reference list—of works made
by artists supported by the gallery that are now in
MoMaA’s collection, for example—would fail to grasp
the unbridled sense of opportunity JAM offered black
artists to try some shit out, and, importantly, to fail.
The logic of speculation can’t grasp what happens in a
space for blackness unconcerned with canon formation
or the constant policing of the borders of worthiness.
‘What kind of future was made possible when JAM.
did not capitalize in the ways other cultural institu-
tions did? Just as the Studio Museum and MoMA.
exist today in forms built upon their earlier selves,
might we imagine JAM’s existence in the present as
commensurate with the resources and accompanying
value systems at its disposal? This is not simply an
assessment of the racial wealth gap, but an observa-
tion of an aesthetic still at work. JAM’s itinerant and
shifting shape is at once a function of the economics
that prompted its landlords to evict it from every space
it occupied and an expression of the kind of prosperity
it alchemized from that reality.

The logic of debt is not confined to finance; it is meta-
physical too. Like unpaid rent, religion is another zone
of life where descriptions of mutual obligation take
extended license. Take, for example, the Mahasanghika
Vinaya, a fifth-century Chinese translation of the ca-
nonical Buddhist text, which diagrams the relationship
of the individual to the collective through the language
of debt:

When one person, thanks to another person, takes
refuge in the Sangha [assembly], it is not easy for
the former to repay the latter. Even if she were to
serve that person for her entire life . . . even then,
it would not be easy to repay him.*

At JAM, like many sites of artistic worship, devotion
undergirded the infrastructural belief system, pro-
viding sacrament “to climb back up into air as if to
burst the throat.”*°

Amid the many unpaid bills in JAM’s records are
carefully kept receipts for the clothing and shoes
Goode Bryant bought for her two children, Kenneth
and Brienin. Just as Goode Bryant insisted on taking
meticulous notes about artist payments, she made sure
her kids showed up prepared for the world. Like debt,
motherhood provided a model for another ongoing
form of payment: what the abolitionist feminist Lisa
Guenther has called the obligation of “bear[ing] the
Other without integrating him or her into the same.”**

AtJAM, artists took license with depictions of
motherhood. When Nengudi’s pendulous R.S.V.P.
sculptures had their New York premiere at the gallery,
in 1977 (see Chronology, p. 39), she contextualized
the works’ inception in an accompanying artist state-
ment: “After giving birth to my own son, I thought of
black wet nurses suckling child after child—their own
as well as others—until their breasts rested on their
knees, their energies drained.”*> Maternal care does not
Tequire conception or childbirth, and for black women
‘has been both “coerced and freely given.”**“Black
women’s labors have not been easy to reckon with
conceptually,” Saidiya Hartman has observed of the
difficulty of grasping black women’s socially reproductive
labors through the figure of the striking worker.7A.
gallery owner who, rather than paying her bills, asked
people questions and held space for the labor of care
is an unlikely figure in certain narratives of revolution.
Black women artists and art workers have provided
the sustenance and service necessary to reproduce
the creative order on which museums like MoMA.
est, yet they have not been recognized for the work of
their imaginations. Nevertheless, Goode Bryant and
those who volunteered at JAM prioritized caring for
and about a broad community, At a time when “Black
nationalism looked like paintings of mothers suckling
their young in pigments of red, black and green,” she
proposed another aesthetic for affiliation,

The business of art and the business of mothering
were at times blurred. Part of volunteering at FAM was
babysitting, picking kids up, dropping her kids off. We all
Rind of hung out at the apartment (Janet Olivia Henry),

Goode Bryant’s Upper West Side home became the
first stop for many artists finding their footing in a new
city, and a second location for gallery operations that
proved more reliable as JAM moved from one place

to another. Linda’s apartment was the place where a lot
of the proposals were written. Everyone just hung out and
worked until they got the project done. There were some
attempts at songwriting, too. There was a woman there—
tall and thin—who played the piano. The space was like an
incubator for all kinds of interesting stuff. You could just go
there and freely toss out suggestions and try to come up with
an idea for a project (Faythe Weaver).

As Goode Bryant’s kids grew up, they contributed
to the gallery’s livelihood, too. Kenny was seven years
old but had clearly picked up pointers on selling art. At one
exhibit, somebody wanted a piece of his artwork but claimed
he couldn’t afford Kenny’s price. So Kenny told him he
could make installment payments and pick it up once it
was paid off (Pat Cummings). Kenneth and Brienin also
provided creative inspiration, modeling for JAM staff
member Pat Cummings’s first children’s book, Willie’s
Not the Hugging Kind (1989; fig. 6), the story of a boy
who becomes reluctant to show physical affection as
he grows into adolescence but learns little by little the
value of physical contact with loved ones.

How do you bear another without insisting that

Intergenerational collaboration sometimes is a bridge;
it can also be a pier from which only the wind reaches

To the Present

Lorna Simpson’s collage Linda (For Ursula inaugural
magazine) (2018; fig. 7) juxtaposes two photographs of
Linda Goode Bryant taken by Dwight Carter, an early
JAM supporter, at the time of the gallery’s founding.
In this visual stutter crowned by an aquamarine stain,
Simpson diagrams how the gallery’s work continues

in the present. After closing JAM, in 1986, Goode
Bryant worked in New York City’s budget office before
becoming a documentary filmmaker and subsequently
starting Project EATS, an urban farming initiative
(see Goode Bryant biography, p. 175). But there are
more structural ways in which JAM’s dispersal continues
in the art and culture worlds everywhere around us.
Ata time when many institutions are racing to problem-
solve their histories of exclusion, JAM provides a model
not only of desegregation but also of disintegration:

a refusal to conform to the self-perpetuating norms of
institutional life. Goode Bryant and I have been collab-
orating on Just Above Midtown: Changing Spaces since
the summer of 2018; it is scheduled to open at The
Museum of Modern Art in the fall of 2022. In that in-
terval, the present has continued to unravel. Covid-19,
which attacks the respiratory system, and the war on
black life, which has made “I can’t breathe” a global

FIO. 7

rallying cry, have highlighted our uneven access to air.
This world on fire is separated from the one in which
JAM emerged perhaps only by degrees of intensity.
The loss of life from unmanned combat drones in Iraq
and Afghanistan, extreme weather events, and hyper-
visible forms of state violence are continuous with

the military-industrial complex that spurred the war
in Vietnam, the aerial spraying of pesticides, and the
disruption of black organizations by COINTELPRO.
Resource hoarding, climate apocalypse, and anti-
blackness continue to be interlocking conditions.
Despite the real changes that have occurred in the
intervening years, the same atmosphere persists.

What does this account of JAM’s refusal to pay the
bills and its use of resources like spirit and care make
perceptible? It’s hard to imagine how art can intervene
in the climate catastrophe without first sensing that art
is nature and the environment, the place from which
materials as traditional as pigment or as iconoclastic as
hair are sourced, as necessary to life as a basket of wild
oats, and the ground to which our processions return
the ash and dust of life. Art can’t intervene in the after-
math of the extrajudicial murders of black people if
we don’t first acknowledge that premature death isn’t
a problem of a /ack of representation in visual culture,
but of a hypervisibility circulated through surveillance
technologies that might require the performance of
subterfuge. And art can’t address resource hoarding
if we don’t first recognize that museum collections
often enclose art in “musty-dank-but-spotless” environ-
ments, as Goode Bryant recognized at age twenty-three

when she called for the liberation of art in an article
that appeared in a black newspaper based in her home
state (fig. 8). To make an art analogy, when David
Hammons installed a sculpture at JAM made from

the unlikely mixture of eggshells, tea bags, roaches,
feathers, hair, and wire above viewers’ heads and called
it Grey Skies over Harlem (1977; fig. 9), he offered a
grisaille assessment of the landscape in which we con-
tinue to find ourselves. To attempt the impossible task
of changing the weather, one must first behold it, must
feel the air above us.

‘What does transformation feel like? It’s tough to
suss out or mark meaningful change under current
conditions, in which progress narratives are typically
used to retrench the status quo. It’s hard to have
the fights necessary to continue a movement when
polite code words and bureaucratic solutions take the
Place of debate, or if elites with concentrated power
Gncluding myself) are afraid of the kind of disagree-
ment that can also elicit trust and camaraderie. But
we can listen for the whispers of revolution. Tradition
and transformation are false dichotomies within a
black culture that often requires us to reinvent our
ways of knowing, so that we sometimes repeat mis-
takes when denied history’s means of transmitting
proper names. Nevertheless, we have learned how to
the tell stories of the people who have come before.

Over the last four years, Goode Bryant and I
have plotted a lot of ideas for how we might channel
the show’s resources to create an infrastructure with

real-life consequences: catalyze a co-op fund for artists
under JAM’s influence to redistribute for themselves;
create what Goode Bryant has called “The Cube,” a
space where art and agriculture might come together
to sustain the essential needs of the community; or
develop Black Currant 2.0, an app which, like few
other social media platforms, would offer a space for
meaningful debate, for going slow and being quiet.
Each offers a model for how the show could heighten
an unbounded, nomadic, and diffracted institutional-
ity, found at once within and beyond the “contexture”
of a museum of modern art. I trust that just as JAM
conceived proposals that did not come to pass but
nevertheless changed its landscape, inside of this proj-
ect’s failures already lies the occasion for us to come
together and fight for new ideas. Disintegration is not
just a refusal of integration; it is a way of remaining up
in the air, unknowable and responsive.* It’s also a way
of staying alive.

Balbancha and Manahatta, January-May 2022

Lorraine O'Grady appeared at the opening for this exhi-
bition wearing a tiara, a cape and a gown made from
180 pairs of white gloves, and a sash reading “Mlle
Bourgeoise Noire 1955.” This was the grand debut of the
alter ego O'Grady had created in response to the exhibi-
tion Afro-American Abstraction, held at PS1 earlier in the
year, whose contents she had found too timid—“art with
white gloves on.”* Many of the artists in that show exhib-
ited at JAM, and O'Grady, who soon started volunteering
at the gallery, got to know them. “! wanted to tell them
what Id felt,” she later recalled, “but in an artistic way."?
And that’s what she did on this evening, handing flow-
ers to the crowd, then lashing herself with a whip and
reciting a poem: “That's enough! No more boot-licking.
... Black art must take more risks!” The beauty queen
rose again the following year at the opening of the New
Museum's exhibition Persona, which featured the work
of nine contemporary artists—all white—who assumed
alter egos or personae “as vehicles for greater freedom
of expression.”* Excluded from the artist list, O'Grady
seized “freedom of expression” on her own terms. On
this occasion, the poem's punchline was “Now is the
time for an invasion!”* —LR

post-modern art isn't the only underexposed, unrecog-
nized art,” as the music critic David Jackson argued in
an unpublished essay written for the show.’ Despite the
mixed reviews it received, Dialogues achieved its goal:

For the visual-art component of Dialogues, the American
Indian Community House Gallery showed the work
of Edgar Heap of Birds. The artist, who belongs to the
Cheyenne and Arapaho nations, created Understanding
the Uniqueness of an Ethnic Entity (1980; plate 49),
which consisted of painted die-cut letters adhered
directly to the wall in two columns: Cheyenne words for
animals were paired with intentional mistranslations in
English. Heap of Birds selected the latter from exhibition
didactics a museum had recently forced him to write to
explain his shift from recognizably “ethnic” to more polit-
ically oriented work." What initially resembled a bilingual
dictionary was actually a record of irreconcilable differ-
ence, an insurgent message about the position of the
Indigenous artist who had to perform their ethnicity for
an audience that had no knowledge of their culture.

Uniquely aware of the power of institutions, Heap of
Birds envisioned a one-person exhibition of his own work,
titled Sharp Rocks, that would travel from one alterna-
tive art space to another, including Just Above Midtown,
in 1984. In his proposal, he framed his paintings, instal-
lations, and videos as modern equivalents to the Native
American arrow point, a traditional tool for self-defense
and preservation.” With Sharp Rocks, which was eventu-
ally realized (though not at JAM), Heap of Birds applied his
Strategic use of language to exhibition making, extend-
ing his means of achieving self-authorship.?, —EB

Just Above Midtown’s move to Franklin Street facili-

first solo exhibition, Maren Hassinger created Beach, a
room-size installation." Composed of wooden dowels
anchored in mounds of painted plaster and sand, the
work appeared to dance across the floor despite being
firmly rooted. Sprouting at various angles, the reed-
like forms all flowed in the same direction, as If a strong,
wind had swept through the gallery. The sculptures
were arranged in organic clusters, prompting viewers
to meander between them in order to experience the
work, and the space, in its entirety. As Lorraine O'Grady
remarked in the exhibition's press release, Beach cap-
tured “the polarity of ‘movement/rest,”” transforming
the gallery into a natural refuge."*

This work resembled one that Hassinger had cre-
ated over the summer for Creative Time's Art on the
Beach 2, an initiative that brought site-specific installa-
tions and performances to the undeveloped beachfront
at Battery Park City, in Lower Manhattan. In response to
the saplings that she saw blowing in the breeze at this
location, Hassinger planted undulating wire ropes in
the sand, tilting them in the direction of the wind. Both
organic and industrial, Forest gestured simultaneously
toward the natural elements of the site and the man-
made skyline that rose behind it. Rather than perma-
nently alter the environment, Hassinger’s temporary
installation was completed by it—reflecting a process
that lives at the intersection of dissonant forces, harmo-
nizing the spaces her work inhabits.

For Outlaw Aesthetics, the first group show held at

unraveled pieces of wire rope resembling palms or dan-

propelling itself by the parallelograms of negative space
between each component. With its repetitive uniformity
andits intrinsic relationship to its environment, the work
maintained what Linda Goode Bryant referred to as a
“balanced union with space.”"*

which also included freestanding cruciform sculptures

buckles backward on her toes, holding her breath. She
releases air and heaves forward, grabbing her mouth
with her right hand and struggling to blow air through
jit. Cut back to Morris, who plays discordant notes as

Nengudi described her act of exhalation in Air

to be gone and .. . this other spirit to come in.”? Her

reflection on the elasticity of selfhood might also be
applied to artistic authorship, and in particular to that
of the installation she made for the performance. Its
shapes and materials referenced Salvador Dali's paint-
ing The Discovery of America by Christopher Columbus
(1958-59), which pictures a sea of ivory-skinned con-
quistadors setting foot in the “New World” amid crosses
and ship sails. Nengudi recontextualized this celebra-
tion of conquest and inspired it with her own breath,
creating a conduit between “Americans” in Columbus's
time and hers. —TJL

Despite their keen awareness of the ways in which

historical canon, Hiller and Lacy committed their own
act of exclusion by not including any Black artists in LA/
London Lab, an omission that bolstered the critique that
most feminist collectives and movements at the time
were not truly inclusive.2* —yK

Randy Williams was a glue at JAM. He came up with
the name for the gallery, made benefit prints for it, and
showed there consistently. Appropriately, in the wood-
framed assemblages he presented in this solo exhibi-
tion, he trained his eye on the devices and materials that

hold other objects together—hooks and nails, thread,
spools, and twine. Having committed to go to the art
supply store as little as possible, he instead sourced
the building blocks for his work from his immediate sur-
roundings: the streets of Manhattan, which he has called
his “eye level,’?” and the Metropolitan Museum of Art,
his employer from 1972 to this day, where he obtained
slides in particular. Williams's polymorphous, focused
use of found objects reflected his reception of both Neo-
Dada and early-twentieth-century African American art,
which he had studied at New York University under Hale
Woodruff. His work also benefited from the useful tech-
niques he had learned from family members, including
his grandfather, a carpenter, and his mother, a dress
patternmaker. —TJL

Janet Olivia Henry—whose work spans installation,
sculpture, collage, design, beadwork, and photogra-
phy—met Linda Goode Bryant while working as a fellow
at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a position Goode
Bryant had held previously. Henry would eventually
work at JAM, where she served as Goode Bryant's fre-
quent interlocutor and designed and edited the gal-
lery’s magazine Black Currant. Henry, who was inspired
by JAM's spirit of curiosity and experimentation, has
described the gallery as a place for “artists who just
wanted to follow their minds.”**

Henry purchased toys, dolls, miniatures, and other
objects and materials from mom-and-pop toy stores,
secondhand shops, flea markets, and yard sales around
New York and arranged her finds in miniature vignettes
inspired by her own life, exploring personal belongings’
capacity for storytelling and symbolism.* Retroactive,
Henry’s solo exhibition at JAM, included action figures
positioned in dioramas; dolls, toys, and detritus in clear
plastic encasings hung on the wall; and juju boxes that
functioned as microcosms of memories and memora-
bilia. Each object or tableau formed a distinctive piece
of a larger whole. Treating dolls and figurines as proxies,
Henry reimagined her world, gesturing toward the intri-
cacies of a life complicated by the implications of race,
gender, migration, and occupation while maintaining
an ethos of play. In the diorama The Studio Visit (1982;
plate 69), for example, a Black woman artist converses
with a white woman curator, the former cocking her
head to the side as she watches the latter hold a frame
to her face. The scene captures the absurdity and the
difficulty of engaging with the predominantly white art
world as a Black artist. Ritual (1982-83), which features
a Black woman outfitted in a yellow robe and slippers,
surrounded by foliage and enjoying a moment of respite,
emphasizes how important—and rare—it is for Black
women to find space for rest and care. —Yk

“The question mark in the title implies that there is no
longer the possibility of a decision by arms,” explained
the press release for this exhibition.*° It went on to
quote Jonathan Schell’s influential three-part article
"The Fate of the Earth,” published earlier in 1982 in
the New Yorker: “The decision by arms can occur only
when the strength of one side or the other is exhausted,
or when its exhaustion is approached. But in a nuclear
war no one's strength fails until both sides have been
annihilated.” Some participating artists directly
addressed the nuclear question. Margia Kramer, for
example, showed Still Life with Rad Gloves (198:
opposite page), a box containing crushed eyeglasses,
a broken watch, and a melted glass Coca-Cola bot-
tle, all accessible only with the attached radiation-
attenuating gloves. Like a time capsule found after a
catastrophe, the work imagines a scenario in which
the artifacts of everyday life have been rendered toxic.
Other artists referenced the ongoing specter of US
imperialism, among them Martha Rosler, whose con-
tribution, a large drawing titled Pie in the Sky and We
Die (1981-82), shows a wraithlike figure in a cowboy hat
watching a bomb descend ona landmass labeled “Latin
America, USSR, Europe, You + Me.” Still others evoked
the terror of modern warfare more generally, as Brigid
Kennedy did in Naked Raid (1981), a trio of eerily feature-
less aerial bombers made of wire mesh and paper and
suspended from the ceiling.

Not all of the works offered such sobering visions.
Dinosaur Project—a collective of twenty artists from
Ithaca, New York—presented Fall Out Fashion, a perfor-
mance showcasing artist-designed clothing for a post-
apocalyptic world, held on Armed Forces Day to empha-
size the connection between militarism and looming
disaster. The garments included a wedding dress that
transformed into a funeral frock, and a dress covered
in small plastic bags for the “survival of the fattest.’”?
Village Voice dance critic Sally Banes wrote that it was “a
relief... to see a group of artists attack the upper crust
of American politics and the clothing industry by sub-
verting the fashion-show format with intelligent wit and
a funky style refreshingly devoid of pretensions.” —BE
