True to JAM’s mission of exploring the structural issues
of the art world—realized through programs like the
Business of Being an Artist (see Chronology, p. 98)—
What | Do for Art addressed a seemingly inescapable
dilemma for artists: how to balance an artistic practice
with a livelihood, Rather than perpetuate the commonly
held view that this is inherently a struggle, the exhibi-
tion brought together twenty visual artists, two perfor-
mance duos, and a musician to demonstrate how artists’
occupations exist in union with their artistic practices,
not apart from them. The show provided a means of rec-
ognizing the totality of artists’ lives when considering
their work.

In an essay in the accompanying catalogue titled
“What Has Been Done for Art,” Lisa Nicol Peters, the
assistant editor of Print Collectors Newsletter, provided
a historical perspective, adeptly tracing the occupa-
tions of artists from ancient Egypt to modern times.**
The book also included a personal statement from each
artist in the show about their relationship to their job—
as a security guard, a minister, a hairdresser, and an
erotic dancer, to name a few—revealing the diversity of
experiences that shaped the work on view.

Daniel Dawson, a curator of photography at The
Studio Museum in Harlem andamember of the Kamoinge
Workshop, a collective of Black photographers, viewed
his art as inseparable from his work.** In both his photo-
graphs and his curatorial practice, he sought to reflect
the transcendent nature of African culture, in which
visual art and music intertwine.*” Sandra Payne, a librar-
jan, wrote that her profession's collecting practices
impacted her own collection of the signs and symbols
that made up her collages and wall installations (see
also Chronology, p. 158).*° She was also deeply influ-
enced by psychic readings. In The Madame C. J. Walker
Beauty Manual . . . (1981), which was included in the

exhibition, Color-aid-paper cutouts of the artist's hands
reference the act of “the laying on of hands,” a symbol
of the psychic’s spiritual relationship with their client. In
other works, Payne made references to the healer, con-
struction worker, seamstress, and archeologist—pro-
fessions that, in the artist's view, created myst
solved dilemmas**—encapsulating the exhibi
versal approach. What I Do for Art proposed a paradigm
shift, or, as Dawson alluded to in his catalogue entry, a
way for artists to circumvent restrictive definitions and
to claim their dynamic place in society. —eB

Resulting performance: Blind Dates, White
Dog Performance Studio, 54 White Street

Over three weeks, the public could watch composer
Yasunao Tone, visual artist Senga Nengudi, and cho-
reographer and dancer Blondell Cummings create
one another during JAM's opening hours in antic-
ipation of an evening at the neighboring White Dog
Performance Studio. The resulting twenty-five-minute
performance was organized into eleven parts and
included both solo and group vignettes.’ In the first sec-
tion, “Polaroiditis,” the three artists paced the stage as
a recording played of them describing the process that
had resulted in what the audience was about to see:
Tone: I knew I had to compromise.

Nengudi: This was such a roller coaster ride.

Cummings: The key was not to control things
the way I usually do.*

Nengudi wore a black dress onto which she had affixed
Polaroid photographs of audience members. Prior to

the evening's performance, she had given out cards
with the following score, titled “Smile”:

I am from California. I want a photo of you
to take home as a memento of my visit. If
you don’t want your picture taken, cover
your face with this card or any way you
choose. Thank you. 5?

Nengudi‘’s costume literally brought the viewers
onstage, creating a ready form of audience participa-
tion and performance documentation. In the second
passage, “FrameWork,” Cummings contorted her face
as she mimed familiar gestures—pointing her finger to
call someone out, showing her palms to signal exaspera-
tion—abstracted from narrative content. She broke fluid
movement into stuttering parts, imitating a camera’s
rapid shutter, then stopped and held her hand above her
head, with one finger raised, in a gesture of confidence.
As the lights came up for the third vignette, “Photo
Essay I,” Tone read aloud in Japanese from a collection of
his essays.®* Then, a film made by the composer, which
featured pictorial translations of the Chinese characters
from three Tang poems—including images of a pagoda,
a palm tree, a skull, and a volcano—was projected on a
screen. Photo conductors converted the film’s shifting
light intensity into sounds resembling percussive tele-
vision static. In the essay he read, Tone theorized that
the meaning of an image occurs “only [within the] con-
text in which [that] image is laid.”** Like photography—a
medium included or referenced in all three artists’
contributions to their collaboration—the performance
insisted on its “blind date” with its context. —TJL

Susan Mogul’s performance The Last Jew in America,
which had its premiere at JAM a few days before
Passover;* examined “processes of assimilation and
‘struggles to maintain ethnic and individual integrity.”*° It
took “the structure and the ritual of the Passover Seder” as
its starting point, with the traditional retelling of the story
of the Israelites’ liberation from enslavement replaced by
Mogul’s irreverent and absurdist monologue, which she
deliveredin the role of “The Last Jew,” “part professor, part
night club comic.”*” Among the topics addressed were the
lack of great Jewish art and artists, Jewish Americans’ rela-
tionship to Chinese food, celebrities whose Jewish her-
itage isn’t well-known, and intermarriage. The rambling
Narrative was punctuated by the introduction of props
including a Sammy Davis Jr. album, across, and handcuffs;
these functioned like the food items on the Seder plate,
each of which represents an aspect of the Passover sto-
ry.** She was one of several artists whose performances at
JAM addressed their lived experience and the labor and
care needed to maintain aspects of their identity.

Another work in this category was The Fine Art of
Waitressing, performed by Madeleine Keller and Janet
Ziff in June 1982 in conjunction with the exhibition What
1 Do for Art (see Chronology, p. 101). Their “multimedia
presentation”*® included a carousel of slides that shed
light on the politics of the service industry, a dramatiza-
tion of interviews with two veteran waitresses, a filmed
demonstration on “The Proper Way to Clear a Table,”
and a fashion show of aprons designed by Ziff.*° The
press release stated that Keller first waited tables at the
SoHo restaurant FOOD; her waitressing career ended
when she was fired from another downtown restau-
rant for her “alleged vulnerability,” an admission that
highlights the emotional labor required of all service
workers. Ziff, on the other hand, was still a waitress and
investing energy into gaining new skills, having recently
returned from a trip to the Riviera to research French
table service.” The Fine Art of Waitressing, whose title
plays with the idea that there is an art to any occupation,
might be understood in relation to the notion of “main-
tenance art.” Formulated by Mierle Laderman Ukeles in
1969, the term offers a critique of art as an elitist realm
of individual creation and elevates the less glamorous
tasks that support and preserve cultural production—in
this case, the non-art labor performed by artists so that
they could afford to be artists at all.°? —tr

The three-night performance Naming Things was the
result of a collaboration—an “electric partnership"—
between three sought-after artists working across
different disciplines.** David Hammons designed the envi-
ronment,** sourcing a casket from a funeral home and sling
beach chairs from a furniture store to create a spare set.**
Philip Mallory Jones made a video installation consisting
of ten monitors that were shifted between scenes.” And
Bill T. Jones wrote a script in three acts with text spoken
by three characters: Writer (Bill T. Jones), Director (Rhonda
Moore), and Dancer (Poonie Dodson).

The first act, “Outing,” took place in a ruined the-
ater in medieval Italy, where the trio performed a
play beneath an abandoned gatehouse inscribed
with the word Paradiso. The second act, “After the
Theatre,” was set in a loft; Director read a review of
the trio’s play that described it as “a series of images
often inscrutable’—one of the performance’s self-re-
flexive nods. “Wake,” the last act, was located in a
funeral home, where Writer lay in rest before sitting
up and reciting a monologue about a “small boat . . .
careening towards the abyss.” At the end of the staged
action, Hammons and Mallory Jones broke the fourth
wall to join Jones onstage; all three sat in the chairs and
discussed the work they had just completed.** —TJL

Undercurrents Gallery

The downstairs space at JAM’s Franklin Street location
hosted solo or two-person shows—often the featured
artists’ first exhibitions in the city. Many of these art-
ists were selected through the gallery's open submis-
sion process or through word of mouth. Among those
in the latter category was Albert Chong, who wandered
into JAM while on a stroll downtown. At the gallery, he
met Fred Wilson and David Hammons, who advised
him to submit work samples, which led to his exhibition
Undercurrents.?

In the photographs Chong was making at the time,
the body often acts as a conduit between the spiritual
world and conceptual art. Minimal Mystic (1982; plate
80), for example, pictures a dissipating figure—a long
exposure of the artist—kneeling in front of a wrinkled
burlap backdrop. This work belongs to Chong’s I-Traits
series (1979-85), which he has described as the “visual
utterances of a culturally misplaced shaman, using art
as a pretext for magic and mysticism.”” The shaman in
Minimal Mystic, even while vanishing, still conjures the
spiritual into the setting. —LAT

JAM was evicted for the second time for nonpayment
of bills and because noise complaints had been filed
against the gallery. Its staff worked out of an office at
225 Lafayette Street until September, when they relo-
cated to 503 Broadway.

assi-34 Afro-Pop

In 1981 Linda Goode Bryant began planning the exhibi-
tion Afro-American Pop Culture, or Afro-Pop for short.’*
With this show, she sought to expand the gallery’s focus
by presenting Black popular culture's contributions
across a variety of realms, including “dance, humor,
fashion, music, food, environments, performance,
games, church, social clubs and oral diaries.”"* Goode
Bryant wanted to commission new installations by David
Hammons, Senga Nengudi, James Andrew Brown, Randy
Williams, Sandra Payne, and Janet Olivia Henry.”* These
artworks would be shown alongside “artifacts, icons .. .
and symbols" such as “straightening combs and hot curl-
ers, funeral photos and church fans with images of Jesus
or Martin Luther King .. . step charts for popular dances,
rare and out-of-print recordings, [and] dream books."””

Goode Bryant's efforts to highlight Black material
culture in a gallery context intersected with contem-
Poraneous projects like Group Material’s 1981 exhibi-
tion People’s Choice: Arroz con Mango, for which the
collective invited their primarily Latinx neighbors in the
East Village to place objects of personal significance on
display, thereby recontextualizing them as art. For the
JAM project, anthropologist John Langston Gwaltney
was hired to create an audio installation from interviews
with artists and cultural producers on Black culture in the
United States.” There were nearly a dozen performances
planned, from Black fraternity and sorority dances to
a multimedia presentation of Black fashion and beauty
culture. The project’s expanding program led to com-
mensurate cost increases, and JAM staff sought to find
volunteers and in-kind donors. Despite receiving sup-
port from several private and public sources, the gallery
‘was unable to raise the necessary funds, and planning
for the project ceased after spring 1984.

Though it never materialized, Afro-Pop shaped
JAM's trajectory, bringing new collaborators into the
gallery's orbit and emphasizing performance as a strat-
egy for exhibiting Black history. Oversight of the exhi-
bition’s music program was delegated to Greg Tate, a
young music critic. Tate proposed a multipart montage
of twentieth-century Black popular music, Arranged
chronologically, the program would have started with
improvisations based on popular jazz standards, then
moved through Black achievements on the guitar and
saxophone, as well as the contributions of gospel, soul,
scat, and swing. With an eclectic artist list that fea-
tured both intergenerational Afro-pop icons such as
Aretha Franklin and younger groups such as DC punks

Bad Brains, Tate’s multi-genre proposal was a fitting
expression of JAM’s vast ambitions and its continued
commitment to an expansive idea of Black art. Tate
went on to edit the JAM periodical B Culture (see
Chronology, p. 155) and to organize musical perfor-
mances at the gallery. —BE

A sculptor, printmaker, photographer, film-
maker, educator, and lifelong activist, Canille
Billops was a key participant in JAM throughout
its existence. By the time Billops showed in
y's inaugural exhibition, Synthesis,
, she had already begun to build Black
institutions of her own. In 1972, Billops and
her husband, James V. Hatch, established the
Hatch-Billops Archive, dedicated to preserving
and celebrating Black artists and culture.
Throughout the decade, Billops photographed
exhibitions and gatherings of Black artists in
Now York City; her pictures, including those
‘sho took at JAM (see the present volune’s jacket
and pp. 1, 4, 24-25, 30, and 47), constitute an
important archive in and of thenselves.

The artist's sculptures dismantle traditional
hierarchies between craft and fine art, at times
taking the form of furniture or other decorative
or utilitarian objects. Inspired by personal
experiences and menories, Billops animated her
sculptures with scenes that address the realities
of racism and sexism. Stylized characters
interact with their sculptural frameworks or—
as in the case of works like Nadam Puisay
(1981)—become the vessels themselves. -&8

Ina well-known origin story, the US alternative-space
movement begins in the 1960s, particularly in New
York, driven by the desire to center unconventional
means of distribution, production, and accessibility,
and to develop exhibition venues beyond traditional
commercial gallery frameworks. It is characterized by
“organizational innovation, creative experimentation,
and attempts to remedy systemic deficiencies,”! in
establishments that value the communitarian, collective,
and anti-elitist. Such spaces eschew standard bureau-
cratic form, privileging the flexible and adventurous
and the needs and agency of local artists. They offer
a critique of both commercialism and aesthetics. One
1960s innovator, Jacki Apple, also describes the art itself
as different, “process-oriented [and] post-Minimal”;
emerging in a conceptual environment that did not
value the market, “the work was temporal, ephemeral,
transitory, performative, and investigatory: process
took precedence over product.”?

The growth of alternative spaces allowed artists of
color and women artists to make greater inroads into
the artworld. One legacy of 1960s and ’70s activism,
these spaces instantiated the model of the artist as citi-
zen intent on changing the world, in a subtle transition
from known forms of political activism to a politics
of representation.? However, if cultural diversity was
valued in the American art universe, it was, more often
than not, seen as part of community connection and
development in ethnic neighborhoods, in Harlem,
Queens, the Bronx, Brooklyn’s Bedford-Stuyvesant,
and Manhattan’s Chinatown and Latinx East Village.
The venues and organizations located in these parts
of the city included The Studio Museum in Harlem,
Weusi-Nyumba Ya Sanaa, El Museo del Barrio,
Fashion Moda, Longwood Arts Center, Jamaica Art
Center, Basement Workshop, and Kenkeleba House.
Even institutions based in the lower Manhattan
cultural district (Hatch-Billops Collection, American
Indian Community House Gallery, Acts of Art, and
Cayman Gallery) were considered more culturally
specific than alternative and often receive cursory
attention in written histories, or do not appear at all.
Ignored by or barred from the art world generally,
folks of color played out their desires for an exhibition-
ary complex, their own will to representation, in these
autochthonous art spaces, which followed from the
more informal churches, cultural centers, and business
offices that had supported and fueled their dreams
earlier in the century.

Linda Goode Bryant figures prominently in this
broader art historical narrative. Her Just Above
Midtown Gallery (affectionately known as JAM) first
took root in New York’s oldest blue-chip art neigh-
borhood, on Fifty-Seventh Street (1974-79), and
later in the emerging downtown districts of Tribeca

(1980-84) and SoHo (1984-86). As Rujeko Hockley
and Catherine Morris have argued, JAM played a
crucial role in 1970s Black avant-garde and experi-
mental arts, supporting a bevy of Black creators, not
only visual artists but musicians and writers. Moving
between for-profit and nonprofit strategies, JAM
embraced a wide array of organizational methods,
professionalized artists and collectors, and, for all
intents and purposes, invented the market for the work
it would show.*

From its inception, JAM vexed established modes
of commerce and representation alike. In the mid-
1970s most of the longstanding New York art world
still did not know what to do with Black artists, outside
of the few stars; Jacob Lawrence, Romare Bearden,
and the meteoric Bob Thompson. It was assumed that
Black artists were amateurs, outliers, or hobbyists.
While some neighboring gallerists—Terry Dintenfass
(who showed Lawrence), Betty Parsons, and Sidney
and Carroll Janis—were supportive, the majority of
Fifty-Seventh Street rejected the investigatory methods
of JAM’s director and artists as much as their race. In
the midst of a recession, Goode Bryant had fearlessly
talked her way into renting the space—724 square feet
on the fifth floor—from owner Bill Judson, and she
and supporters rehabbed the place, putting in parquet
floors. Their excitement notwithstanding, JAM’s first
home, located in the back of the building and lack-
ing windows, mirrored the cramped spaces that had
historically been available to Black artists in the United
States and abroad: the children’s galleries, the foyers
and hallways, the project rooms, and the smallest gal-
leries in any museum.>

Some of the earliest documents in the JAM archives
reveal Goode Bryant’s prescience and point to the
unwavering vision that would guide her over the twelve
years she spent crafting a gallery with national and in-
ternational reach, twinned commercial and educational
portfolios, and programming that supported a creative
community and championed multimedia, installation,
and performative practices.

JAM’s first show, Synthesis (fig. 1) (see Chronology,
p. 29), like the gallery itself (see opposite page), came
with a definition: “a combination of parts or elements
into a complex whole.”* The exhibition made space
for a larger, global Black art world.” The West Coast

delegation included Dan Concholar, David Hammons,

and RoHo; Alonzo Davis and Suzanne Jackson, who
were also gallerists; and Los Angeles native Camille
Billops, who had already (with her husband, James

V. Hatch) established, in New York’s SoHo, the
Hatch-Billops archival and oral history project, which

For the gallery’s fourth anniversary, in 1978,
Goode Bryant produced not only a signature show but
a book that came to define the art of a generation
(see Chronology, p. 40).° In Contextures (fig. 2), she
traced the parameters of “Contexturalism,” which
she saw in the flexible, noncommercial, and for the most
part nonrepresentational, mixed media, and perfor-
mative practices of Hammons, Senga Nengudi (fig. 3),
Houston Conwill, Maren Hassinger, Howardena
Pindell, and others. As theorized by the gallerist, these
artists used “remains” (inchoate but not completely
indeterminant matter) whose site, margins, or context
defined them as art; engaging the sensate and the sonic
along with ritual action, the Contexturalists imbued
“abstract and conceptual systems with content.”!?

In the summer of 1979 JAM closed its space on
Fifty-Seventh Street. A year later it reopened in the
rawer, hipper arts neighborhood of Tribeca with an
amended moniker, Just Above Midtown/Downtown.
Now with two floors and a significantly larger footprint,
JAM doubled its number of exhibitions, increased
workshops and lectures, and opened its doors to an
ever-widening array of practices and the diversity
that downtown itself represented. Live projects by
Hassinger, Lorraine O’Grady, Kaylynn Sullivan

‘TwoTrees, William Pope (aka Pope.L), Martha Rosler,
and Linda Montano would become indelibly asso-
ciated with the birth of the alternative-space scene.
Events featured musicians such as Steve Reich and
Lawrence D. “Butch” Morris (the latter in collabora-
tion with Nengudi and dancer Cheryl Banks-Smith);
Hammons, dancer Bill T. Jones, and media artist
Philip Mallory Jones created an “Electric Partnership”
(see Chronology, pp. 91 and 108). Houston Conwill

“Culture is always changing, and the alternative
task is to interpret that transformation. Dissatisfaction
with the ordinary art world is the motivation to create
another dimension.”"! In this statement, Papo Colo
sums up the will to innovate that drove him, Goode
Bryant, and others in the community they made down-
town. JAM presented a solo show of his work in 1982,
the same year he and his partner, Jeanette Ingberman,
started their own gallery, Exit Art, on Broadway in
SoHo. A few years later JAM would move just two
blocks down the street. In the gallery’s last location,
Goode Bryant focused on building a laboratory where
artists could create in real time. Instead of exhibition
space, there were areas for artists to think and make
(and perhaps change the world). For Goode Bryant
the curatorial process was no longer memorialized in
objects but contained in living possibilities that held
out “an alternative or corrective to the failures of
mainstream institutions and ideologies.”!

that drove it and kept the gallery afloat for more than
a decade, despite inequities of funding, recognition,
and sponsorship. Goode Bryant’s focus, intent, and

in NewYork in 1972 to her opening the first commer-

art world’s premier commercial centers just two years

Cummings, Lowery Stokes Sims, and Faythe Weaver,

downtown, artists including Lorraine O’Grady and
Janet Olivia Henry volunteered. Matching these
women’s very real day-to-day engagement was their
innovative and radical critical and art historical work,
through which they made a place for JAM, and them-
selves, in the world.

In 1972, in the wake of its missteps with the Harlem
on My Mind exhibition of 1969, the Metropolitan
Museum of Art hired Sims in Education and Community
Programs; by 1974 she was the first—and for decades
would be the only—Black curator at what is arguably
this country’s most visible museum. In an art world
that clung to the trappings of certain types of formal
schematics, Sims insisted on a détente between
figuration and abstraction. Like Goode Bryant, she
foregrounded artists whose “critical practices” and, to
a certain degree, “overt subject matter” upset “assump-
tions about forms, materials, conventions of represen-
tation, or the institutional framework of art.” Writing
in Arts Magazine, Artforum, and High Performance,
she began to elucidate a broader investigative field for
Black artists, sketching the significance of Robert

Colescott and Wifredo Lam, and of live work by
Urban Bush Women and Thought Music. She also
wrote reviews of shows at JAM, including Noah
Jemison’s solo presentation in 1977. Judith Wilson,

a Californian, was more directly a part of the art
journalism apparatus. Wilson turned to art writing

in the late 1970s, covering shows at JAM and the
Studio Museum and the artists in those circles, such

and Beverly Buchanan, in popular publications like
Ms, Essence, and the Village Voice. Faythe Weaver—
like Goode Bryant a native of Columbus, Ohio, and a

reviewed JAM and Studio Museum exhibitions in

the Amsterdam News, New York’s Black paper of record
throughout the twentieth century. However, it was
Coker who first opened the door to more substantive
writing on art in that outlet when she approached
senior cultural writer Mel Tapley with the idea in the
late 1970s. Initially an artist and a member of Where
We At, a collective of Black women creators, Coker
wrote articles for the Amsterdam News on a wide range
of topics: solo shows of Betye Saar’s work, historical
African and Haitian art, art collecting, and exhibitions
at Cinque Gallery, Tim Blackburn Gallery, and JAM,
where the work of Black artists could always be found.
By the 1980s Coker would increasingly appear in

the record as a curator. With Horace Brockington she
organized the Art Across the Park series, which
brought temporary work by Hassinger, O’Grady,
Billops, Lydia Okumura, Ana Mendieta, and others to
public parks throughout New York City, inspired by
JAM’s philosophy, strategies, and artists.'®

Evident in the writing by Sims, Wilson, Weaver,
and Coker is a captivation with the participatory
practices that became a signature of JAM. Coker’s take
on JAM’s 1978 summer show It’s a Crowd describes
the feel of works tumbling into the viewer while they
navigate the gallery.!7 Her review of The Process as Art:
In Situ, which took place later the same year, examines
a project that shifted over weeks as it attempted to
teveal the creative process, with the public welcome
to watch.'* Here we find JAM and Goode Bryant
continuing to explore the boundaries between per-
formance and visual art, and intuitively shaping the
laboratory model that would energize the gallery’s last
iteration, at 503 Broadway.

In this particular story of Black feminism, Goode
Bryant and this network of women—in physically
Pulling the gallery together, keeping it going, and
creating an intellectual space for it to thrive—pushed
against the parochialisms of the art world itself.!
More broadly, they sought to demolish the calcified
traditions and worldviews that had existed for cen-
turies, instantiated with colonialism and enslavement,
and formalized as the inequities in life and cultural
Possibility that followed. For this writer, the art world

“culture wars” of the late twentieth century did not
commence in 1989 with the targeting of queer imag-
ery, or in 1993 with outcries against a more diverse
biennial at the Whitney Museum—they were sewn into
the fabric of American life from the outset. However,
one earlier moment, in 1979, made vivid the contest of
power and visibility. And Goode Bryant, Pindell, Sims,
‘Wilson, and many others weighed in.

In Jeff Chang’s thorough retelling of the Nigger
Drawings controversy of 1979, it is Henry’s visit to
the infamous show at Artists Space, in SoHo, that set
protest and refusal in motion, alerting the community
around JAM to the artist Donald Newman’s titling of
his exhibition of charcoal pictures with the expletive,
as a way to indicate the works’ lowly origin.” Black
artists and their supporters pushed back with a rapid
letter-writing campaign to funding agencies, repudi-
ating white artists who were “smug & secure” in their
mobilizations of a “racial slur used under the guise of
aesthetic freedom”! and “tawdry sensationalist tactics”?
that challenged a Black humanity.

Monologic discourse was cracking under the
weight of more encompassing global theory and the
practices of artists and cultural workers worldwide
that took it up.” Art was not a white neighborhood,
and neither was New York’s downtown. A year later
Linda Goode Bryant would open JAM on Franklin
Street, a pioneer in Tribeca, bringing a capacious and
ever-evolving “theoretical context for the work of

black artists.”**

When JAM was located in Tribeca and then SoHo, it
played a vital role in the downtown theater and per-
formance community. Performers and playwrights as
diverse as Adrienne Kennedy, Lenora Champagne, and.
Daryl Chin submitted work for consideration or were.
featured in JAM’s program. Among its peers, JAM was
a uniquely important space for performance by Black,
Brown, and Indigenous women, who were often cre-
atively responding to exclusion and violence experi-
enced across generations. Among them were Kaylynn,
Sullivan TwoTrees (then Sullivan) and the members of
the company Spiderwoman Theater, all of whom incor-
porated memory and oral history into “counterprac-
tices” that addressed the daily challenges and stereo-
typical representations faced by women of color, while
playing with the capacity of performance to bridge the
divide between the world of the studio or gallery andlife,
beyond it.*

TwoTrees joined the JAM community at Franklin
Street as a performance artist with a background in
dance and theater; she also served as a consultant to
the gallery. Her debut work, Victims (1981), addressed,
domestic violence and was grounded in a childhood
story of murder in her family. Audience members were
presented with a series of vignettes in the form of
video footage, audio recordings, and a performance by
‘TwoTrees and Tone Blevins, all while the smell of roast-
ing chicken filled the space.* The work concluded with
the audience eating the freshly cooked meal, which.
reinforced the association that had been established
between nourishment, consumption, and violence, and
brought the audience into the situation they had just
witnessed." As Robert Massa wrote in the Village Voice,
the work “was not only ‘conceived’ but ‘actualized’
through TwoTrees's experimentation with the dual role
of witness and participant.” In Victims (plural), collec
tive participation offered a creative means to disruptthe
‘experience of the victim (singular).

‘over her nearly fifty-year career, Linda Goode
Bryant has assumed mony roles: gallery owner,
filmmaker, farmer, entrepreneur, and activist. In each
position, she has advocated “our innate ability to use
Wat we have to create what we need” and developed
niving installations” that feature collaborative activities
capable of changing the circumstances of those who
porticipate in them.

‘Goode Bryant was born in Columbus, Ohio, in1949,
and earned a bachelor of arts degree in painting from
‘Spelman College. She moved to New York City to pur-
suea master’s degree in at history at City College in
1972, and two years later opaned Just Above Midtown
AN), a gallery centered on African American artists,
and artists of color. At each of its three locations, in
Midtown, Tribeca, and SoHo, it offered early—and
often unique—opportunities to artists, providing
space and money for them to experiment freoy,
unconstrained by art-market pressures. After closing
JAM in 1986, Goode Bryant—who hed received an
MBA from Columbia University in 1980—worked
a senior policy analyst for development in Mayor
David Dinkins’s administration. In the mid-1990s she
decided to dedicate herself to filmmaking. Her doo-
Flag Wars (2003), codirected with Laura
,, was shot over four years in Goode Bryant's
hometown, An intimate portrait of a community
<dealing with the tension between preservation and
sentrifcation, it received numerous honors, includ-
ingan Emmy nomination and a Peabody. Other films
by Goode Bryant include Hurricane Teens (1998) and
Can You See Me Now? (2006), collaborative projects

that explore young people and community formation
in New York City and beyond. Her workin film earned
her a Guggenhoim Fellowship in 2004,

In 2004, Goode Bryant also established the Active
Citizen Project (ACP) to involve disenfranchised and
non-voting youth and adults around the country
in crafting and campaigning for local and national
platforms that addressed issues important to them.
In2009, ACP’s work shifted from elections to Project
EATS, a network of small-plot, high-yield farms and
rolated programs located in low-income communities
‘throughout New York, including Belmont and Mott
Haven in the Bronx and Brownsville and Cypress Hill
in Brooklyn. Goode Bryant continues to experiment
with methods of connecting culture, nature, and

sustenance through new kinds of creative collective
production. In 2024, she collaborated with archi-
tect Elizabeth Diller on Are we really that diferent?,
an installation that brought farming and video into
‘conversation as part ofthe exhibition Social Works at
New York's Gagosian Gallery. The following year, she
served as artistic director of RAW Académie at ICA:
Infrastructure, a seven-week residential program at
the Institute of Contemporary Artin Philadelphia that
‘sought to relmagine the possiblities for an alternative
arts infrastructure,
